Graphical abstract Mg(OH)2 can significantly improves the electrocatalytic performance of Cu2O(1 1 1) by promoting the activation of CO2 molecules and facilitating C–C coupling processes. The Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst has a C2 to C1 ratio of about 3.5, which is 3.5 times higher than the ratio of approximately 1.0 for the Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst. Copper-based electrocatalysts hold significant promise for driving the reduction of CO2 to generate high-energy–density fuels and valuable chemicals. Nevertheless, achieving high selectivity for specific products remains a formidable challenge due to the intense competition among multiple reaction pathways. In this study, we investigate the role of Mg(OH)2 modification on Cu2O(1 1 1) catalysts in enhancing the selectivity for multi-carbon (C2) products during the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR). The results show that the Mg(OH)2-modified Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst (Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2) achieves a C2 product selectivity of up to 68%, significantly higher than that of the pristine Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst. Characterization techniques, including scanning electron microscope (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), confirm the successful incorporation of Mg(OH)2 onto the Cu2O(1 1 1) surface and reveal its porous structure. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations and in situ attenuated total reflection surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) demonstrate that Mg(OH)2 effectively activates CO2 molecules, lowers the adsorption energy barrier, and promotes C–C coupling, thereby enhancing C2 product selectivity. This study provides valuable insights into the design of efficient electrocatalysts for selective CO2 reduction to multicarbon products. Among these, the production of multi-carbon (C2+) products, such as ethylene and ethanol, is highly desirable due to their wide-ranging applications in the chemical and energy sectors [4,5]. However, achieving high efficiency and selectivity for C2+ products in CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) remains a significant challenge because of the competitive nature of the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and the broad spectrum of potential products, combined with the intricate and interconnected reaction pathways involved [6,7]. Cu-based materials exhibit a moderate binding energy with the CO intermediate (*CO), aligning with the Sabatier principle. This balance ensures that *CO adsorbed on the Cu surface is neither too weakly bound to desorb rapidly nor too strongly bound to cause catalyst poisoning [8]. Furthermore, Cu displays a more negative adsorption energy for *CO compared to a positive adsorption energy for hydrogen intermediate (*H), which effectively suppresses the HER [9]. These properties render Cu an effective catalyst for the electrochemical CO2 reduction, facilitating the production of multi-carbon products. Nevertheless, the inherent activity of Cu-based catalysts remains suboptimal. A multitude of strategies have been employed to enhance their catalytic activity [10], such as surface structure regulation [11], doping with heteroatoms [12,13], alloying [14,15], and surface modification [16,17]. Among these, the surface modification of Cu-based catalysts for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction has garnered widespread attention due to its ability to offer a versatile approach to enhance the electrocatalytic performance by improving selectivity, stability, and activity [18–20]. Lin Zhuang et al. [21] discovered that the carbonyl group in quaternary ammonium poly can activate CO2 molecules, thereby reducing the reaction energy barrier. When modified on a Cu electrode, it leads to a high coverage of *CO, promoting C–C coupling to produce C2H4. In a pure water CO2 membrane electrolyzer, a cell voltage of only 3.54 V was needed to achieve a total current density of 1000 mA/cm2, with the Faradaic efficiency (FE) for C2H4 reaching nearly 50 %. Robert H. Grubbs et al. [22] found that a tri-component copolymer-modified Cu catalyst significantly increased the gas diffusion porosity on the catalyst surface, which in turn increased the local CO2 concentration at the electrode surface. This enhancement in competitive adsorption capacity for CO2 molecules resulted in high selectivity for C2H4 (55 %) and C2+ products (77 %). Victor Mougel et al. [23] utilized 1-octadecane thiol to modify and construct superhydrophobic surfaces on Cu dendritic catalysts. In neutral electrolytes, the hydrophobic electrode showed a FE of 56 % for C2H4 and 17 % for C2H5OH, whereas the more hydrophilic Cu dendritic catalysts had FE of 9 % and 4 %, respectively. The hydrophobic Cu dendritic surface was found to capture CO2 gas, increasing the CO2 concentration at the electrode-solution interface, thereby enhancing the selectivity for CO2 reduction. In our previous reports [24–27], we have used organic molecules/polymers such as polyaniline, polydopamine, Nafion, and 7,7,8,8-tetracyanoquinodimethane to modify commercial Ag and Cu catalysts for enhancing the performance of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. The results indicate that these organic molecules/polymers can not only regulate the activity of CO2 and H2O molecules but also influence the adsorption behavior of intermediate species, thereby improving the performance of electrocatalytic CO2RR. Unfortunately, these modifiers may excessively encapsulate catalyst particles during the modification process, affecting the transport of electrons and protons, resulting in low current density. Therefore, the utilization of inorganic materials for electrode surface modification may present a potential alternative avenue, although this approach has garnered scant attention [1,28]. Gongwei Wang et al. [29] synthesized a Cu/CeO2 heterojunction catalyst, adjusting the Cu loading to regulate its interface properties. They found that the interface properties alter the ratio of low − and high − frequency *CO intermediates, impacting C2+ product selectivity. At 40 % Cu loading, the optimal ratio of these intermediates was achieved, granting the catalyst a remarkable 63 % C2+ selectivity. Qiang Wang et al. [30] synthesized a CuMgAl-LDH catalyst via an atom isolation approach. The introduction of Mg atoms was found to maintain the high dispersion of Cu atoms during the catalytic process, serving as a barrier against Mg atom aggregation. This action suppressed the dimerization of *CO intermediates, thereby promoting the deep reduction of CO2 to CH4. Here, we demonstrate that modifying the surface of Cu2O(1 1 1) nanoparticles (NPs) with a functional Mg(OH)2 shell can significantly enhance the selectivity for C2 products during the electrocatalytic CO2RR. Compared to pristine Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst, the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst exhibit remarkable performance improvements. Specifically, the FE for CO2 reduction increases from 40 % over Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst to 68 % over the optimized Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst at −1.4 V vs. RHE. Notably, the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst achieves a 56 % FE for C2H4 and a 12 % FE for CH4 at −1.4 V vs. RHE. Through comprehensive characterizations and theoretical calculations, we elucidate the underlying mechanism for the enhanced selectivity: the Mg(OH)2 shell effectively activates CO2 molecules, generating a higher coverage of *CO intermediates that favor C–C coupling to form C2 products. Our findings highlight the potential of Mg(OH)2 as a versatile surface modifier for Cu-based catalysts, offering a new strategy to improve the efficiency and selectivity of CO2 electroreduction to multicarbon products. 2 Results and discussion The Cu(1 1 1) and Mg(OH)2/Cu(1 1 1) catalysts were synthesized using a hydrothermal method, as detailed in the experimental section of the supporting information. Fig. 1 a presents a schematic diagram of the preparation process for the series of catalysts. Briefly, 3.33 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) was added to 100 mL of a 10 mM CuCl2 aqueous solution and stirred at room temperature until fully dissolved. The solution was then heated to 55 °C, and 10 mL of a 3 M KOH aqueous solution and 10 mL of a 0.6 M ascorbic acid aqueous solution were added dropwise. The reaction was maintained at 55 °C with continuous stirring for 1 h. After the reaction, the product was washed and dried to obtain the Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst. For the synthesis of Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1) catalysts, the same initial steps were followed to prepare the Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst. However, before the centrifugal washing step, a calculated amount of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O was introduced into the reaction mixture, and the reaction was continued for an additional hour. Upon completion, the resulting catalyst was washed and dried to yield the Mg(OH)2-modified Cu2O(1 1 1) catalysts. The obtained samples are denoted as Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-x, where x corresponds to the quantities of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (x = 1 for 25 mg, x = 2 for 50 mg, x = 3 for 75 mg, x = 4 for 100 mg, and x = 5 for 125 mg). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was utilized to examine the morphological features of the Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst. Fig. 1b presents the SEM analysis, which reveals the distinctive octahedral morphology of the Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst, characterized by a pristine and smooth surface. A series of Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1) catalysts, synthesized by modulating the quantity of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O introduced, were also subjected to SEM analysis, as illustrated in Fig. 1c and Fig. S1. Upon the decoration of Mg(OH)2, the surface of the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst exhibited a marked increase in roughness, which increased progressively with the increment of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O. Despite the increased roughness, the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1) catalysts maintained a regular octahedral structure, indicating that the Mg(OH)2 modification does not alter the inherent morphology and structure of the Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was utilized to investigate the morphological characteristics of the Cu2O(1 1 1) and Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalysts, as depicted in Fig. 1e–h. The TEM image in Fig. 1e reveals that the Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst exhibits a distinct octahedral structure with a clean and smooth surface. High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) analysis, shown in Fig. 1f, highlights well-defined lattice fringes with a d-spacing of 0.21 nm, characteristic of the Cu2O(111) plane. This observation indicates that the Cu species in the Cu2O(111) catalyst are in the Cu+ state, consistent with the findings from XRD analysis. Upon modification with Mg(OH)2, the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(111)-2 catalyst, as illustrated in Fig. 1g, shows a rougher surface. The HRTEM image of the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(111)-2 catalyst, presented in Fig. 1h, also reveals clear lattice fringes with a d-spacing of 0.21 nm, confirming that the Cu species in the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(111)-2 catalyst remain in the Cu+ state. This suggests that the chemical state of the Cu species is preserved between the Cu2O(111) and Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(111)-2 catalysts. Furthermore, an approximately 2 nm thick amorphous layer is observed on the surface of the Cu2O(111) catalyst, which is attributed to the presence of Mg(OH)2. The TEM images of series Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(111) catalysts suggest the thickness of Mg(OH)2 gradually increases with the increase in Mg(NO3)2·6H2O dosage as shown in Fig. S2. However, the thickness of the Mg(OH)2 layer significantly affects the electrocatalytic CO2RR performance (as detailed in the performance analysis section). A thick Mg(OH)2 layer may reduce the accessibility of CO2 and H2O molecules, impacting the mass transfer process during electrocatalytic CO2RR [31]. Fig. 1d displays the energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectra of Cu, Mg, and O, clearly indicating the successful modification of Mg(OH)2 onto the surface of the Cu2O(111) catalyst. X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectroscopy was conducted to examine the structural characteristics of the Cu2O(1 1 1) and a series of Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1) catalysts, as depicted in Fig. 1i and Fig. S3. The XRD patterns reveal that both Cu2O(1 1 1) and Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1) catalysts exhibit identical diffraction peak signals. The peaks observed at 29.5°, 36.4°, 42.3°, 61.4°, and 73.7° correspond to the (1 1 1), (2 0 0), (2 2 0), (3 1 1), and (2 2 2) planes of the Cu2O phase, respectively (PDF#99-0041). The isotherms reveal that the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst exhibits a hysteresis loop, indicating a rich pore structure. To investigate the mechanism of the effect of Mg(OH)2 on the electrocatalytic CO2RR pathways of the Cu2O(1 1 1) catalysts, in situ attenuated total reflection surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) was used to monitor the key intermediates during the electrolysis process. The device schematic is depicted in Fig. 3 a, and the detailed experimental procedure is provided in the supplementary material. The experiments were carried out in a CO2-saturated 0.5 M KHCO3 solution. The spectral data was gathered between −0.4 V and −1.4 V vs. RHE, with the spectrum at −0.3 V vs. RHE being used as the baseline reference. As shown in Fig. 3b and 3c, both the Cu2O(1 1 1) and Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalysts exhibit a strong absorption peak at around 1400 cm−1, attributed to the *COOH intermediate [41]. The normalized intensity of the *COOH intermediate is summarized in Fig. 3d. It can be observed that the peak intensity of *COOH increases with increasing polarization potential on both Cu2O(1 1 1) and Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalysts, indicating that the electrocatalytic CO2RR kinetics depend on the polarization potential. However, under the same polarization potential conditions, the peak intensity of the *COOH intermediate is significantly higher for the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst compared to the Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst. This suggests that CO2 molecules have a higher reactivity on the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst. This could be related to the Lewis acid-base interaction between the Mg(OH)2 and CO2 molecules, which effectively activates CO2 molecules and reduces their reaction energy barrier [42]. Additionally, a signal peak corresponding to the *CO2 – intermediate was detected at 1253 cm−1 on both catalysts. This intermediate arises from the activated adsorption of CO2 molecules on the catalyst surface. The absorption intensity of the *CO2 – intermediate on the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst was higher than that observed on the Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst as shown in Fig. 3g, indicating that Mg(OH)2 can activate CO2 molecules and enhance their reactivity. Generally, *COOH is identified as a necessary intermediate for the generation of *CO intermediates [43–45]. As shown in Fig. 3b and 3c, a *CO intermediate absorption peak is detected at around 2037 cm−1 for the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst and at 2045 cm−1 for the Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst. The normalized intensities of the *CO intermediate on Cu2O(1 1 1) and Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalysts are summarized in Fig. 3e. It can be observed that the *CO intermediate absorption peak is significantly stronger for the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst compared to the Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst, indicating a higher *CO intermediate coverage on the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst. Higher *CO intermediate coverage is more favorable for C–C coupling [46–48], leading to the formation of multi-carbon products. Additionally, the intensity of the *CO intermediate increases and then decreases with increasing polarization potential on both catalysts. The decrease in *CO intermediate peak intensity is associated with the coupling process between *CO intermediates [28,49]. However, the *CO intermediate peak intensity on the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst begins to decrease at −0.8 V vs. RHE, while for the Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst, it begins to decrease at −1.1 V vs. RHE. This indicates that the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst is more favorable for the formation of multi-carbon products. Moreover, *OCCO intermediates [41,50], derived from C–C coupling, were detected at 1549 cm−1 and 1564 cm−1 on the Cu2O(1 1 1) and Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalysts as shown in Fig. 3b and 3c, respectively. The normalized peak intensities of *OCCO intermediates are summarized in Fig. 3f. The peak intensity of *OCCO intermediates increases with increasing polarization potential on both catalysts. However, the intensity of *OCCO intermediates on the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst is significantly higher than that on the Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst, indicating a higher selectivity for C2 products on the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst, which is consistent with the analysis of the electrocatalytic CO2RR performance. In summary, the Mg(OH)2 layer exhibits a synergistic effect with the Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst, effectively activating CO2 molecules and generating a high coverage of *CO intermediates, thereby promoting the C–C coupling process and improving the selectivity of C2 products. Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations further confirm the crucial role of Mg(OH)2 in the CO2 reduction reaction process, as illustrated in Fig. 4 . Fig. 4a shows the reaction free energies for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction on Cu2O(1 1 1) and Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalysts, as shown in Fig. 4a. The results reveal that the adsorption and hydrogenation of CO2 molecules are energetically uphill processes. However, the introduction of Mg(OH)2 significantly lowers the energy barriers for these processes on the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst surface, facilitating the formation of higher-coverage *CO intermediates. Generally, a higher coverage of *CO intermediates is favor in C–C coupling. To further elucidate this reaction process, we calculated the free energy diagram of *CO intermediate dimerization on Cu2O(1 1 1) and Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalysts as shown in Fig. 4b. The Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst has a reaction barrier of 1.78 eV. Nevertheless, the incorporation of Mg(OH)2 substantially reduces this energy barrier to 1.28 eV, revealing that the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst is more conducive to the formation of C2 products. Fig. 4c shows that the adsorption free energy of CO2 molecules on the Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst surface is −0.25 eV, while on the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst surface, this value drops significantly to −0.49 eV. This indicates that Mg(OH)2 can interact strongly with CO2 molecules, thereby reducing the activation energy barrier for CO2 and enhancing the electrocatalytic performance of the Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst in CO2 reduction. Based on these findings, Fig. 4d and 4e depict the possible mechanisms of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction on Cu2O(1 1 1) and Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalysts. On the Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst, the adsorption and activation of CO2 molecules is a kinetically slow process, resulting in the formation of low-coverage *CO intermediates. In contrast, the introduction of Mg(OH)2 facilitates a strong interaction between the Mg(OH)2 layer and CO2 molecules, effectively activating CO2 and accelerating the formation of *CO intermediates. This leads to high-coverage *CO intermediates on the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst surface. High-coverage CO intermediates are known to be critical for the formation of multicarbon products. Therefore, the Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst predominantly produces C1 products, while the Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst favors the formation of C2 products. 3 Conclusions This study provides comprehensive insights into the role of Mg(OH)2 modification in enhancing the selectivity for C2 products during the electrocatalytic CO2RR over Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst. The introduction of Mg(OH)2 significantly improves the electrocatalytic performance of Cu2O(1 1 1) by promoting the activation of CO2 molecules and facilitating C–C coupling processes. Characterization techniques, including XRD, SEM, TEM, and XPS, confirmed the successful incorporation of Mg(OH)2 onto the Cu2O(1 1 1) surface and revealed its porous structure, which enhances the transfer of CO2 and H2O molecules to the active sites. DFT calculations and in situ ATR-SEIRAS demonstrated that Mg(OH)2 lowers the adsorption energy barrier for CO2 molecules and increases the coverage of *CO intermediates, thereby promoting the formation of C2 products. The Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2 catalyst exhibited a C2 product selectivity of up to 68 %, significantly higher than that of the pristine Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst. This study highlights the potential of Mg(OH)2 as an effective surface modifier for Cu-based catalysts and provides valuable insights for designing efficient electrocatalysts for selective CO2 reduction to multicarbon products. coredata.dc:description: Copper-based electrocatalysts hold significant promise for driving the reduction of CO2 to generate high-energy–density fuels and valuable chemicals. Nevertheless, achieving high selectivity for specific products remains a formidable challenge due to the intense competition among multiple reaction pathways. In this study, we investigate the role of Mg(OH)2 modification on Cu2O(1 1 1) catalysts in enhancing the selectivity for multi-carbon (C2) products during the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR). The results show that the Mg(OH)2-modified Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst (Mg(OH)2/Cu2O(1 1 1)-2) achieves a C2 product selectivity of up to 68%, significantly higher than that of the pristine Cu2O(1 1 1) catalyst. Characterization techniques, including scanning electron microscope (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), confirm the successful incorporation of Mg(OH)2 onto the Cu2O(1 1 1) surface and reveal its porous structure. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations and in situ attenuated total reflection surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) demonstrate that Mg(OH)2 effectively activates CO2 molecules, lowers the adsorption energy barrier, and promotes C–C coupling, thereby enhancing C2 product selectivity. This study provides valuable insights into the design of efficient electrocatalysts for selective CO2 reduction to multicarbon products.
